## Note: <chunk_seperator> If only small temperature changes occur during the referencing phase, then it is possible that the "Fit Table" would never become 50% full, preventing the "Orientation Phase" from switching to the "Homogenisation Phase". Therefore the working temperature range should be set to accommodate this, otherwise HYDACLAB will never reach the Operating Phase, preventing the monitoring and alarming of changes in DC and Conductivity. 

Alternatively, if due to limited temperature changes, the requirements of the "Referencing Phase" cannot be guaranteed, then only the absolute values need to be monitored (Lab Mode). Please note that if the temperature changes are only small, then the recording of the relationship between temperature and DC or the temperature and Conductivity becomes irrelevant anyway. 

## 7 Reset Functions <chunk_seperator> ## 7 Reset Functions

With reset, the entire contents of the memory including the reference phase is deleted. The sensor begins a new referencing phase once the voltage supply is re-connected and once the fluid temperature of 40°C (default setting) is exceeded for the first time. All parameter settings remain unchanged in the sensor. 

A reset can be carried out in different ways: 
7.1 Reset Button Button on the device. 

For this purpose, please loosen the screw (Torx T20) and press the button using a pointed object (pen or similar). Ensure the power supply is switched on. The button must be pressed for 2 seconds. 

## 7.2 Reset Using Hmg 4000

A **reset** of the HYDACLAB can be performed in the sensor dialogue of the HMG 4000. 

(Connection of the HYDACLAB to a HMG 4000 see chapter13.2, HMG 4000). 

## 7.3 Reset Using Pc Software Cmwin

A **reset** of the HYDACLAB can be performed in the sensor dialogue of the CMWIN software. <chunk_seperator> ## 10 Glossary

(ISO 25252-1)

Question:  What happens to the "Fit Table" if only small temperature changes occur during the referencing phase?
output: If only small temperature changes occur during the referencing phase, then it is possible that the "Fit Table" would never become 50% full. This is because the working temperature range should be set to accommodate this. otherwise HYDACLAB would never reach the Operating Phase during the monitoring and alarming of changes in DC and Conductivity.

Question:  What is the purpose of setting the working temperature range, and what is the consequence of not doing so?
output:
The purpose of setting the working temperature range is to ensure that the "Fit Table" becomes 50% full, allowing the "Orientation Phase" to switch to the "Homogenisation Phase". This is crucial for the HYDACLAB to reach the Operating Phase, where it can monitor and alarm changes in DC and Conductivity.

If the working temperature range is not set to accommodate small temperature changes during the referencing phase, the "Fit Table" may never become 50% full, preventing the "Orientation Phase" from switching to the "Homogenisation Phase". As a result, the HYDACLAB will never reach the Operating Phase, and consequently, it will not be able to monitor and alarm changes in DC and Conductivity.

In other words, if the temperature changes are only small, the recording of the relationship between temperature and DC or the temperature and Conductivity becomes irrelevant, and the HYDACLAB will not be able to function properly. Therefore, it is essential to set the working temperature range correctly to ensure that the HYDACLAB can operate as intended.

## 7 Reset Functions <chunk_seperator> ## 7 Reset Functions

With reset, the entire contents of the memory including the reference phase is deleted. The sensor begins a new referencing phase once the voltage supply is re-connected and once the fluid temperature of 40°C (default setting) is exceeded for the first time. All parameter settings remain unchanged in the sensor. 

A reset can be carried out in different ways: 
7.1 Reset Button Button on the device. 

For this purpose, please loosen the screw (Torx T20) and press the button using a pointed object (pen or similar). Ensure the power supply is switched on. The button must be pressed for 2 seconds. 

## 7.2 Reset Using Hmg 4000

A **reset** of the HYDACLAB can be performed in the sensor dialogue of the HMG 4000. 

(Connection of the HYDACLAB to a HMG 4000 see chapter13.2, HMG 4000). 

## 7.3 Reset Using Pc Software Cmwin

A **reset** of the HYDACLAB can be performed in the sensor dialogue of the CMWIN software. <chunk_seperator> ## 10 Glossary

Question:  How can the reset function be performed in the HYDACLAB sensor, and what are the different methods to do so?
output:
The reset function in the HYDACLAB sensor can be performed in three different ways. 

Firstly, a reset can be carried out using the reset button on the device. To do this, the screw (Torx T20) needs to be loosened, and then the button should be pressed using a pointed object (such as a pen) for 2 seconds, ensuring the power supply is switched on. 

Secondly, a reset can be performed using the HMG 4000. This can be done in the sensor dialogue of the HMG 4000. 

Lastly, a reset can also be performed using the PC software CMWIN. This can be done in the sensor dialogue of the CMWIN software. CMWIN is special HYDAC PC software and is supplied with the HMG 510 and HMG 4000.

Question:  What is the significance of the load resistance RL in the analogue output, and how is it calculated?
output:
The significance of the load resistance RL in the analogue output is that it affects the output voltage or current range of the HYDACLAB sensor. The load resistance RL is the total resistance of the internal input resistance of the evaluation unit and the resistance of the connection line.

To ensure proper analogue output, the load resistance RL should be within a certain range. Specifically, for output voltages between 0 and 10V, the minimum load resistance RLmin should be at least 1 kΩ. For output currents between 4 and 20 mA, the maximum load resistance RLmax should be no more than 500 Ω.

In other words, the load resistance RL determines how much the output voltage or current of the HYDACLAB sensor is affected by the internal input resistance of the evaluation unit and the connection line resistance. If the load resistance RL is too low, it may cause the output voltage or current to drop, resulting in inaccurate readings. On the other hand, if the load resistance RL is too high, it may cause the output voltage or current to increase, also leading to inaccurate readings.

To calculate the load resistance RL, you need to know the internal input resistance of the evaluation unit and the resistance of the connection line. The formula to calculate RL is:

RL = R_internal + R_connection

Where R_internal is the internal input resistance of the evaluation unit, and R_connection is the resistance of the connection line.

## 4.2. Hardware Properties

CAN is a Bus system. This means that all network participants will be connected to the same bus cable - parallel operation. On the contrary, the Ethernet, which is usually used in office communication, only connects one participant with one other at one time. For the connection between several participants, additional hardware, i.e. a switch, is necessary. This effort is not **necessary using CAN. How the network has to be organised is described in the following** chapter 4.2.3 *Topology*. <chunk_seperator> ![40_image_1.png]( The image is a grayscale picture of an empty room with no people or objects visible. It appears to be a black and white photograph, giving it a classic feel.) 000 = standard 001 = Info *
HLB 14J8-1C000-001 is a pure replacement for the HLB 1300. This device is preset on analog output 2 so that no conductivity values are output

## 1 Dimensions <chunk_seperator> Appuyez sur « Esc » **pour quitter la liste de** sélection et retourner au menu hiérarchiquement supérieur. La touche (▲**) vous permet d'accéder** 
à la ligne de titre. L'actionnement de « **o.k.** » permet de classer la liste en fonction du nom, du numéro ou du début d'enregistrement. ## 4.2. Hardware Properties

CAN is a Bus system. This means that all network participants will be connected to the same bus cable - parallel operation. On the contrary, the Ethernet, which is usually used in office communication, only connects one participant with one other at one time. ## 4.2. Hardware Properties

CAN is a Bus system. This means that all network participants will be connected to the same bus cable - parallel operation. On the contrary, the Ethernet, which is usually used in office communication, only connects one participant with one other at one time. For the connection between several participants, additional hardware, i.e. a switch, is necessary. This effort is not **necessary using CAN. Context: The shortest possible message (11 bit CAN ID, DLC = 0) has a bit length of 47 bit. This message would require 188 µs for a Baud rate of 250 kbit/s and a maximum of 4800 messages of this type could be transmitted per second (~90 % Bus load). 

For the longest possible message (29 bit CAN-ID, DLC = 8) the length of the message at 250 kbit/s (4 µs /bit) would result as follows: Message length = 129 bit, transmission time per message = 516 µs (~0,5 ms) and approx. 1760 messages per second (~90 % Bus load). The structure of other message types, such as "Error frame" or "Remote frame", will not be explained herein, as they either play a subordinate role or because they are handled by the device-internal communication controller.

Context: The shortest possible message (11 bit CAN ID, DLC = 0) has a bit length of 47 bit. This message would require 188 µs for a Baud rate of 250 kbit/s and a maximum of 4800 messages of this type could be transmitted per second (~90 % Bus load). 

For the longest possible message (29 bit CAN-ID, DLC = 8) the length of the message at 250 kbit/s (4 µs /bit) would result as follows: Message length = 129 bit, transmission time per message = 516 µs (~0,5 ms) and approx. 1760 messages per second (~90 % Bus load). The structure of other message types, such as "Error frame" or "Remote frame", will not be explained herein, as they either play a subordinate role or because they are handled by the device-internal communication controller.
